column5: anyone tried this out? My ropes pooched but ive never really messed around with paracord. i figure i could switch it out each year if it starts to wear down?  Im considering making my own G force handle at some point using a lawn mower replacement handle and Dog tie coated cable. Lil DYI project.,
Go to a small engines shop and get a replacement pull cord for a lawn mower. Para cord will only let you down in a short time.  S.

Replacing the broken cord on my Motor Guide was fairly simple really. I think if I remember I used a stiff piece of wire leader  as a fish line with the cord tapped to it. I always keep some cordage and a roll of electrical and duct tape on the boat. It took all of 10 minutes. I always intended to change it to a better quality cord but it is still there. Now I have another to do when it stops snowing.
They have pull cord @ Canadian Tire.
$13.00 for the same handle on amazon and a couple of feet of aircraft cable and you are good to go!
i found the right handle, they make them for lawn mowers and now all of a sudden i cant find it!

I used parachute cord from Walmart to hold down the tarps on my wood piles, that stuff seemed to deteriorate quickly when exposed to sun  and weather. I replaced one once and use braided nylon similar to light anchor rope.

https://www.amazon.ca/gp/aw/d/B00164ANLU/ref=mp_s_a_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1523716103&sr=8-3&pi=AC_SX236_SY340_QL65&keywords=lawn+mower+handle&dpPl=1&dpID=41pKIRZzT4L&ref=plSrch  i know Canadian Tire used to sell them too.
Th marine.. makes steel cable and pull handle. Have one om my motorguide digital and.my.112 foretrex never need another again
I know they do, and they want $50 for an 8 dollar handle and $4 worth of coated cable...i think this should make for a nice DIY project when I have a moment. Thanks for finding me it again lape!

as others have said, paracord is not a good idea except in an emergency.  The "REAL THING" has 550 pound breaking strength, but the sheath around the nylon fibres is apt to separate. I think this is one of those areas where the OEM part is a good idea......... Doug
